ai-ud2.1:1.2_0: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the root of the Mucalinda tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
ai-ud2.1:1.3_0: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
ai-ud2.1:2.1_0: Just then an unseasonal storm was approaching, with seven days of rain, cold winds, and clouds.
ai-ud2.1:2.2_0: Mucalinda, the dragon king, came out from his abode. And he encircled the body of the Buddha with seven coils and spread his large hood over his head.
ai-ud2.1:2.3_0: “May the Buddha not be hot or cold, nor be touched by horseflies or mosquitoes, by the wind or the burning sun, or by creeping animals and insects.”
ai-ud2.1:3.1_0: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion.
ai-ud2.1:3.2_0: When he knew the sky was clear, Mucalinda unwrapped his coils from the Buddha’s body. Hiding his own form, he manifested in the form of a brahmin youth. He stood in front of the Buddha, venerating him with joined palms.
ai-ud2.1:4.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud2.1:5.1_0: “Seclusion is bliss for the contented one,
ai-ud2.1:5.2_0: who see the teaching they have learned.
ai-ud2.1:5.3_0: Kindness for the world is happiness
ai-ud2.1:5.4_0: who taskled creatures to living beings,
ai-ud2.1:6.1_0: Dispassion for the world is happiness
ai-ud2.1:6.3_0: But dispelling the conceit ʻI am’
ai-ud2.1:6.4_0: This, indeed, is the highest bliss.”
